message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Consensus reaching process in large-scale group decision making based on bounded confidence and social network
Paper Abstract: Consensus reaching process (CRP) is a dynamic and interactive method used to reach a group decision. Now that social networks and mobile internet are prominent features in daily life, more experts are able to take participate in decision making in the network and their opinions are influenced by others in the decision-making process. Therefore, how to use the difference of opinions and the relationships between experts to promote the consensus is an important issue. This paper proposed a CRP approach for large-scale group decision-making based on bounded confidence and social network to manage experts’ opinions. Firstly, a fast unfolding algorithm was used to reduce the dimension of the large-scale and the experts’ weights were obtained by social network analysis. Secondly, the CRP was built based on the Manhattan distance, and the feedback mechanism was developed to adjust experts’ opinions based on bounded confidence and social network when the experts did not reach a consensus. A numerical example was used to show the feasibility of the proposed approach and the results illustrated that the consensus speed was faster and the information managed more efficiently. The comparisons with other approaches showed the advantage of our proposed approach. Finally, simulation experiments were given to verify the effectiveness of our proposed approach.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Manhattan distance:

## Definition

Manhattan distance is a distance function (or metric) where the distance between two points is defined to be the sum of the absolute differences of their respective Cartesian coordinates. The name refers to the island of Manhattan, or generically any planned city with a rectangular grid of streets, in which a taxicab can only travel along grid directions.

## Alternative Names

The taxicab distance is also sometimes known as rectilinear distance or L1 distance. It's formally known as taxicab geometry or taxicab distance.

## Practical Applications

In a grid plan, the travel distance between street corners is given by the Manhattan distance: the number of east–west and north–south blocks one must traverse to get between those two points. Manhattan distance is commonly used in GPS applications, as it can be used to find the shortest route between two addresses.

## Geometric Properties

In taxicab geometry, the distance between any two points equals the length of their shortest grid path. Unlike Euclidean geometry where distances follow a straight line, Manhattan distance measures distance as if you can only move horizontally or vertically along a grid.

The taxicab distance is also sometimes known as rectilinear distance or L1 distance. It's formally known as taxicab geometry or taxicab distance.

## Practical Applications

In a grid plan, the travel distance between street corners is given by the Manhattan distance: the number of east–west and north–south blocks one must traverse to get between those two points. Manhattan distance is commonly used in GPS applications, as it can be used to find the shortest route between two addresses.

## Geometric Properties

In taxicab geometry, the distance between any two points equals the length of their shortest grid path. Unlike Euclidean geometry where distances follow a straight line, Manhattan distance measures distance as if you can only move horizontally or vertically along a grid.

Web search results for query: "Consensus reaching process"

Links: [{"title":"Consensus decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_decision-making"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Consensus"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Activating a consensus discussion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Activating_a_consensus_discussion"},{"title":"Scientific consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_consensus"},{"title":"Consensus (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Method for consensus building - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Method_for_consensus_building"},{"title":"Wikipedia:What is consensus? - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:What_is_consensus"},{"title":"Delphi method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delphi_method"},{"title":"Formal consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_consensus"},{"title":"Consensus forecast - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_forecast"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of the consensus reaching process:

## Definition and Core Concept

Consensus is reached when everyone in the group assents to a decision (or almost everyone) even if some do not fully agree to or support all aspects of it.(no content)It differs from simple unanimity, which requires all participants to support a decision.

## Key Principles

Participants in an effective consensus process should strive to reach the best possible decision for the group and all of its members, rather than competing for personal preferences. Additional important principles include:

- Egalitarianism: All members of a consensus decision-making body should be afforded, as much as possible, equal input into the process, with all members having the opportunity to present and amend proposals.
- Inclusion: As many stakeholders as possible should be involved in a consensus decision-making process, and the consensus process should actively solicit the input and participation of all decision-makers.

## Process Structure

The consensus decision-making process often has several roles designed to make the process run more effectively, with the most common being the facilitator, consensor, a timekeeper, an empath and a secretary or notes taker.

## Handling Disagreement

When there is potential for a block to a group decision, both the group and dissenters in the group are encouraged to collaborate until agreement can be reached.

Consensus-based decision-making is used across various contexts, from community organizations to academic and scientific fields, offering a collaborative alternative to majority voting systems.

Links: [{"title":"Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Social network analysis software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis_software"},{"title":"International Network for Social Network Analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Network_for_Social_Network_Analysis"},{"title":"Social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network"},{"title":"Social network analysis in criminology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis_in_criminology"},{"title":"Dynamic network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_network_analysis"},{"title":"Semantic social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_social_network"},{"title":"Network homophily - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_homophily"},{"title":"Cognitive social structures - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_social_structures"},{"title":"Duocentric social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duocentric_social_network"}]

Here are the search results for **Social network analysis**:

## Overview

Social network analysis (SNA) is the process of investigating social structures through the use of networks and graph theory.(no content)It characterizes networked structures in terms of nodes (individual actors, people, or things within the network) and the ties, edges, or links (relationships or interactions) that connect them.

## Applications

Examples of social structures commonly visualized through social network analysis include social media networks, meme proliferation, information circulation, friendship and acquaintance networks, business networks, knowledge networks, difficult working relationships, collaboration graphs, kinship, disease transmission, and sexual relationships.(no content)Social network analysis has found applications in various academic disciplines as well as practical contexts such as countering money laundering and terrorism.

## Historical Development

Social network analysis has its theoretical roots in the work of early sociologists such as Georg Simmel and Émile Durkheim. In 1934 Jacob Moreno and Helen Jennings introduced basic analytical methods. In 1954, John Arundel Barnes started using the term systematically to denote patterns of ties.(no content)Starting in the 1970s, scholars such as Ronald Burt, Kathleen Carley, Mark Granovetter, David Krackhardt, Edward Laumann, Anatol Rapoport, Barry Wellman, Douglas R. White, and Harrison White expanded the use of systematic social network analysis.

## Key Metrics

Metrics encountered in social network analysis include those measuring the size, the nature of connections between members being analyzed, distribution, and segmentation - including subsets such as multiplexity, propinquity, density, centrality, and cohesion.

Links: [{"title":"Group decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_decision-making"},{"title":"Effective group decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Effective_group_decision-making"},{"title":"Category:Group decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Group_decision-making"},{"title":"Consensus decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_decision-making"},{"title":"Participative decision-making in organizations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participative_decision-making_in_organizations"},{"title":"Nominal group technique - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nominal_group_technique"},{"title":"Groupthink - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Groupthink"},{"title":"Oranga Tamariki Act 1989 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oranga_Tamariki_Act_1989"},{"title":"Laboratory rotation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laboratory_rotation"},{"title":"Boing Boing (April single album) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muah!"}]

I've found comprehensive information about group decision-making. Here are the key findings:

## Definition

Group decision-making (also known as collaborative decision-making or collective decision-making) is a situation faced when individuals collectively make a choice from the alternatives before them.(no content)The decision is then no longer attributable to any single individual who is a member of the group.

## Advantages and Disadvantages

Groups, by definition, are composed of two or more people, and for this reason naturally have access to more information and have a greater capacity to process this information. However, they also present a number of liabilities to decision-making, such as requiring more time to make choices and by consequence rushing to a low-quality agreement in order to be timely.

## Common Decision-Making Methods

Social decision schemes are the methods used by a group to combine individual responses to come up with a single group decision. These include authority schemes where leaders make decisions, averaging individual decisions, and voting on preferences.

## Potential Challenges

Group polarization can occur at times, leading some groups to make more extreme decisions than those of its individual members, in the direction of the individual inclinations. Additionally, when individuals make decisions as part of a group, there is a tendency to exhibit a bias towards discussing shared information, as opposed to unshared information.

## Techniques for Effective Group Decision-Making

The nominal group technique (NGT) is a group process involving problem identification, solution generation, and decision-making that can be used in groups of many sizes who want to make their decision quickly, as by a vote, but want everyone's opinions taken into account.

I've found comprehensive information about group decision-making. Here are the key findings:

## Definition

Group decision-making (also known as collaborative decision-making or collective decision-making) is a situation faced when individuals collectively make a choice from the alternatives before them.(no content)The decision is then no longer attributable to any single individual who is a member of the group.

## Advantages and Disadvantages

Groups, by definition, are composed of two or more people, and for this reason naturally have access to more information and have a greater capacity to process this information. However, they also present a number of liabilities to decision-making, such as requiring more time to make choices and by consequence rushing to a low-quality agreement in order to be timely.

## Common Decision-Making Methods

Social decision schemes are the methods used by a group to combine individual responses to come up with a single group decision. These include authority schemes where leaders make decisions, averaging individual decisions, and voting on preferences.

## Potential Challenges

Group polarization can occur at times, leading some groups to make more extreme decisions than those of its individual members, in the direction of the individual inclinations. Additionally, when individuals make decisions as part of a group, there is a tendency to exhibit a bias towards discussing shared information, as opposed to unshared information.

## Techniques for Effective Group Decision-Making

The nominal group technique (NGT) is a group process involving problem identification, solution generation, and decision-making that can be used in groups of many sizes who want to make their decision quickly, as by a vote, but want everyone's opinions taken into account.

Web search results for query: "Feedback mechanism"

Links: [{"title":"Feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback"},{"title":"Positive feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Positive_feedback"},{"title":"Negative feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_feedback"},{"title":"Ice–albedo feedback","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ice–albedo_feedback"},{"title":"Feed forward (control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feed_forward_(control)"},{"title":"Servomechanism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Servomechanism"},{"title":"Myogenic mechanism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myogenic_mechanism"},{"title":"Motor control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_control"},{"title":"Hormone - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hormone"},{"title":"Serotonin–norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serotonin–norepinephrine_reuptake_inhibitor"}]

Here are the search results for "feedback mechanism":

## Overview

A feedback mechanism is based on the study of circular causal feedback mechanisms, which became central to cybernetics from the 1940s onwards.(no content)Mathematicians and theorists interested in the principles of feedback mechanisms prefer the definition of "circularity of action", which keeps the theory simple and consistent.

## Types of Feedback

There are two main types of feedback mechanisms:

**Positive Feedback:** Positive feedback is a process that occurs in a feedback loop where the outcome of a process reinforces the inciting process to build momentum.

**Negative Feedback:** A system in which the results of a change act to reduce or counteract it has negative feedback.

## Applications

Feedback mechanisms are used across many fields:

- **Control Systems:** The most common general-purpose controller using a control-loop feedback mechanism is a proportional-integral-derivative (PID) controller.

- **Biology:** The rate of hormone biosynthesis and secretion is often regulated by a homeostatic negative feedback control mechanism.

- **Engineering:** In servomechanisms, the speed or position of an output, as determined by a sensor, is compared to a set value, and any error is reduced by negative feedback to the input.

- **Motor Control:** Feedback control is a situated form of motor control, relying on sensory information about performance and specific sensory input from the environment in which the movement is carried out.

- **Engineering:** In servomechanisms, the speed or position of an output, as determined by a sensor, is compared to a set value, and any error is reduced by negative feedback to the input.

- **Motor Control:** Feedback control is a situated form of motor control, relying on sensory information about performance and specific sensory input from the environment in which the movement is carried out.

I've completed a web search for "Opinion dynamics consensus" and found several relevant results. Here's what I found:

## Key Findings

Consensus dynamics, also known as agreement dynamics, is an area of research at the intersection of systems theory and graph theory that studies how a group of agents—such as robots, sensors, or decision-makers—interacting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange.(no content)Mathematical models of social learning aim to model opinion dynamics in social networks.(no content)When consensus is reached, the belief of each agent is a weighted average of agents' initial beliefs.

### The DeGroot Model

According to the DeGroot model, each agent takes a weighted average of their neighbors' opinions at each step to update their own belief.(no content)Provided that a network is strongly connected (so there is a direct path from any agent to any other) and satisfies a weak aperiodicity condition, beliefs will converge to a consensus.

### The Sznajd Model

Another important model in opinion dynamics is the Sznajd model, a sociophysics model introduced in 2000 to gain fundamental understanding about opinion dynamics.(no content)The model states: Social validation—if two people share the same opinion, their neighbors will start to agree with them; and Discord destroys—if a block of adjacent persons disagree, their neighbors start to argue with them.(no content)Consensus dynamics has applications in areas such as physiological systems, gene regulatory networks, large-scale energy systems, and coordinated control of autonomous vehicle fleets on land, in the air, or in space.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Fast unfolding algorithm modularity"

Links: [{"title":"Louvain method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louvain_method"},{"title":"Modularity (networks) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modularity_(networks)"},{"title":"Fast folding algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_folding_algorithm"},{"title":"Leiden algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leiden_algorithm"},{"title":"Unfolding (DSP implementation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unfolding_(DSP_implementation)"},{"title":"Modularity of mind - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modularity_of_mind"},{"title":"Girvan–Newman algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Girvan–Newman_algorithm"},{"title":"Community structure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_structure"},{"title":"Modular decomposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_decomposition"},{"title":"Modular exponentiation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_exponentiation"}]

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about the Fast Unfolding algorithm and modularity. Here are the key findings:

## Fast Unfolding Algorithm (Louvain Method)

Modularity is a scale value between −1 (non-modular clustering) and 1 (fully modular clustering) that measures the relative density of edges inside communities with respect to edges outside communities.(no content)In the Louvain Method of community detection, first small communities are found by optimizing modularity locally on all nodes, then each small community is grouped into one node and the first step is repeated.

## How It Works

The Louvain method works by repeating two phases. In phase one, nodes are sorted into communities based on how the modularity of the graph changes when a node moves communities. In phase two, the graph is reinterpreted so that communities are seen as individual nodes.(no content)For each node v, we consider how moving v from its current community C into a neighboring community C' will affect the modularity of the graph partition. We select the community C' with the greatest change in modularity, and if the change is positive, we move v into C'; otherwise we leave it where it is.

## Limitations

A common issue with the Louvain algorithm is the resolution limit of modularity - that is, multiple small communities being grouped together into a larger community. To address these issues, it is recommended to use the Leiden algorithm instead, as its refinement phase and other various adjustments have corrected these issues.

message_text:
Excellent! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (proposes a new consensus reaching approach)

**Identified 7 Key Technologies and Methodologies:**

1. **Consensus decision-making** (concept) - Uses the existing concept of consensus-based group decision-making
2. **Group decision-making** (task) - Addresses the primary problem of large-scale collaborative decisions
3. **Consensus dynamics** (concept) - Leverages existing theory on how opinions converge in networks
4. **Social network analysis** (method) - Uses SNA to determine expert weights and relationships
5. **Taxicab geometry** (concept) - Uses Manhattan distance to measure opinion differences
6. **Feedback** (concept) - **Proposes** a new feedback mechanism to dynamically adjust expert opinions
7. **Louvain method** (method) - Uses the fast unfolding algorithm to reduce data dimensionality

**Validation Status:** ✅ All checks passed
- Paper type correctly identified
- 7 triples documented with proper entity types
- All Wikipedia URLs verified and accessible
- Validation requirements met (minimum 1 "uses" and 1 "proposes" for contribution papers)

The analysis shows this is a contribution paper that combines existing techniques (consensus dynamics, social network analysis, and the Louvain method) with a novel feedback mechanism to improve consensus reaching in large-scale group decision-making scenarios.

Sources:
- [Consensus decision-making](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_decision-making)
- [Group decision-making](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_decision-making)
- [Consensus dynamics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics)
- [Social network analysis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis)
- [Taxicab geometry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taxicab_geometry)
- [Feedback](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback)
- [Louvain method](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louvain_method)
